pageData.text: Discover the characteristics of <button class='glossary-text'>buffered</button> solutions and the important role they play in the environment and living systems. Stock solutions that will be the buffers are prepared. Then, on the basis of calculations, buffers of targeted pH and concentrations are prepared. These prepared buffers are then tested to demonstrate how a buffer maintains pH as compared to non-buffered solutions. Three buffered solutions of varying concentrations will be tested to determine the impact of concentration on buffering capacity.

There are many solids found in tap water that will affect your calculations. Bottled, purified, or filtered water from a home water purifier (e.g., Brita<sup class='bodySupscript'>®</sup> or PUR<sup class='bodySupscript'>®</sup>) should be used.

Determine the proportions of each chemical needed to produce the targeted buffering capacity.

pageData.text: Humans and animals share the fact that our skin produces a chemical called sebum, which keeps our skin and hair, or fur, moisturized and gives it a healthy shine. However, sebum also attracts dust, pollen, and dirt. Shampoos contain substances called surfactants, which lower the surface tension of water, making water more likely to bind with oils and dirt rather than itself so unwanted substances are more easily removed. If these surfactants were used alone, the pH of the shampoo would be too alkaline and cause hair damage. <button class='glossary-text'>Buffer</button> systems, such as citric acid and sodium hydroxide, are used in shampoos to lower the pH. Buffers are found in other personal care products, such as baby lotion. The optimal pH of baby lotion is around six, which slows down the growth of bacteria and other pathogens that can be particularly harmful to a baby.

pageData.desc: A dog in a tub being rubbed down with soap suds.
pageData.altText: A dog in a tub being rubbed down with soap suds.

pageData.text: A is a solution that resists change in pH upon addition of acidic or basic components. Thus, a solution can be buffered to prevent large shifts in pH upon the addition of H+ or OH-. Typically, buffered solutions are composed of a weak acid and its conjugate base or a weak base and its conjugate acid. Buffered solutions prevent large shifts in pH when H+ ions or OH- ions are added. Typically, buffered solutions are composed of a weak acid and its conjugate base or a weak base and its conjugate acid. Buffers can also be prepared from a weak acid with a small amount of strong base, a weak base with a small amount of strong acid, or from an amphoteric substance. An amphoteric substance is an oxide that can act as both an acid and a base. A buffered system exists in equilibrium. Any acid added to the solution will be neutralized by the weak base [A- in the equations] causing a shift in equilibrium towards the weak acid. Any base added will be neutralized by the weak acid [HA in the equations], shifting the equilibrium left.Weak Acid/Conjugate Base Equation: HA ⇄ H+ + A-If Acid is added to the buffer system: HA ← H+ + A-

If Base is added to the buffer system: HA → H+ + A-The buffers used in this lab activity will be made from a weak acid, acetic acid, and its conjugate base, sodium acetate. The descriptions and calculations in the background section will refer to buffers prepared as a weak acid with conjugate base.It is important to remember that acids and bases will dissociate in aqueous solutions. The is the equilibrium constant of the dissociation reaction of an acid in aqueous solution, representing a dynamic balance between the acid in its intact and dissociated states. Most buffers perform best at a pH near the (-log10 Ka, a logarithmic representation of the acid dissociation constant) of the acid used for their preparation. When designing a buffer, the chemicals used should have pKas that are close to the target pH.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: Typically, buffered solutions are composed of a weak acid and its conjugate base or a weak base and its conjugate acid. Buffers can also be prepared from a weak acid with a small amount of strong base, a weak base with a small amount of strong acid, or from an amphoteric substance. An amphoteric substance is an oxide that can act as both an acid and a base. A buffered system exists in equilibrium. Any acid added to the solution will be neutralized by the weak base [A<sup class=bodySupscript>-</sup> in the equations] causing a shift in equilibrium towards the weak acid. Any base added will be neutralized by the weak acid [HA in the equations], shifting the equilibrium left.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: Typically, buffered solutions are composed of a weak acid and its conjugate base or a weak base and its conjugate acid. Buffers can also be prepared from a weak acid with a small amount of strong base, a weak base with a small amount of strong acid, or from an amphoteric substance. An amphoteric substance is an oxide that can act as both an acid and a base. A buffered system exists in equilibrium. Any acid added to the solution will be neutralized by the weak base [A<sup class=bodySupscript>-</sup> in the equations] causing a shift in equilibrium towards the weak acid. Any base added will be neutralized by the weak acid [HA in the equations], shifting the equilibrium left.

img.alt: Equations and descriptions after second paragraph in the Background Section

pageData.text: Most perform best at a pH near the of the acid or base used. When designing a buffer, the chemicals selected should have a pKa close to the targeted pH.The pH of a buffered solution can be calculated using the . Note: Brackets in an equation such as [Acid] refer to the concentration.pH = pKa + log ([Conjugate Base]/[Weak Acid])

As described above, when protons or hydroxide ions are added to the solution the equilibrium shifts and the ratio of acid to conjugate base is altered. The stoichiometry of the new system must be calculated before any equilibrium calculations can be done. This means that the equilibrium calculations must be performed prior to calculating the pH of the solution.

When a buffer is prepared from a weak acid and its conjugate base, there will be some protons present in the buffer solution due to the ionization of the weak acid.Because the equilibrium constant for this reaction is based on the weak acid Ka, added OH- ions combine with the protons to produce water. This causes the ionization equilibrium to shift to the right and more of the weak acid must dissociate to reestablish the equilibrium.

title: Table 1.

CH<sub class=bodySubscript>3</sub>COOH<sub class='bodySubscript'>(aq)</sub> ⇄ H<sup class='bodySupscript'>+</sup><sub class='bodySubscript'>(aq)</sub> + CH<sub class='bodySubscript'>3</sub>COO<sup class='bodySupscript'>-</sup><sub class='bodySubscript'>(aq)</sub>

pageData.text: An can be helpful in determining the concentration of species when equilibrium shifts occur. In the example in there is an acetic acid/acetate buffer with an initial acetic acid concentration of 0.033 M and an initial acetate concentration of 0.056 M. Some concentration of base is added to the system, which results in a loss of x on the acid side of the equilibrium and adding x to both species on base side (shown in Table 1). Using the pKa and the calculated concentrations you can then determine pH.However, the Henderson-Hasselbalch equation is typically used to design a buffer of a targeted pH. If the target pH and the pKa of the acid are inserted into the equation, then you can calculate the ratio of the acid to its conjugate base.

The buffering capacity of a solution indicates the amount of H+ or OH- ions the is able to absorb without a significant pH change. The buffering capacity of a solution is determined by the magnitude of [HA] and [A-]. Therefore, increasing the quantity of each species will increase the buffering capacity. However, the species ratio must be kept similar to maintain the desired pH.To prepare a buffered solution of a specific pH and buffer capacity:

text: Decide which conjugate acid-base pair to use. A buffer is most effective when the acid-base pair have approximately equal concentrations. For this reason, it is best to select a compound with a <button class='glossary-text'>pK<sub class=bodySubscript>a</sub></button> that is within one pH unit of the desired pH. The buffering range is usually within ±1 pH unit of the pK<sub class=bodySubscript>a</sub>.

Next, decide the concentration of the buffer. Since the buffer component concentration determines its buffering capacity, the amount of added H<sup class=bodySupscript>+</sup> or OH<sup class=bodySupscript>-</sup> that the buffered solution could encounter should be calculated.

pageData.altText: This map outlines the workflow for this investigation. Before starting any activities, you will label cups and pipets with solution names, calculate the mass of sodium acetate needed to make a sodium acetate solution, and determine the reactant volumes to prepare pH buffer solutions. In Activity 1, you will create or obtain eight different solutions, including three different pH buffer solutions. Then, you will mix these solutions together in different combinations within a 24-well plate. You will also observe the pH of each well via a pH indicator color change. Next, you will create a fresh batch of 4.7 pH buffer solution which you will add to the wells of a clean 24-well plate. You will then create three dilutions of the pH buffer solution and add these to the 24-well plate. You will add increasing volumes of sodium hydroxide to the plate wells and observe the pH of each well via a pH indicator color change. Finally, you will calculate the molar concentration of sodium acetate in each dilution.

pageData.title: Pre-Lab Assessment Introduction
pageData.text: Directions: Complete this pre-lab assessment to continue to the rest of the investigation. You will need a score of 100% to pass the assessment. This assessment can be attempted as many times as necessary to achieve a passing score. You may return to the pre-lab sections to study before each attempt.<span class=bodyParaLineBreak>For each question, select your response and then click Submit to see how you did. Click Next to continue to the next question. A final results page will appear upon completion of this assessment with your overall performance.

You have unlimited attempts to pass this assessment. Click the Review Pre-Lab button to be returned to the start of the pre-lab section.
Read through the Activity completely.
Collect all the materials.
Clean and sanitize the work area.

Label the eight plastic cups with the solution names. The eight solutions are:
  1. water
  2. 0.1 M acetic acid
  3. 0.1 M sodium acetate
    • Calculate the mass of sodium acetate (CH3COONa) required to prepare 50 mL of a 0.10 M sodium acetate solution, the molar mass is 82.03 g/mol.
  4. 0.1 M NaOH
  5. 0.1M HCl
  6. pH 3.7
  7. pH 4.7 buffer
  8. pH 5.7 buffer

Determine the volumes of 0.10 M CH<sub class=bodySubscript>3</sub>COOH and 0.10 M CH<sub class=bodySubscript>3</sub>COONa required to prepare 10 mL of the following pH buffers: pH 4.7, pH 5.7. (Note: the <button class='glossary-text'>pK<sub class=bodySubscript>a</sub></button> of CH<sub class=bodySubscript>3</sub>COOH = 4.7.) Use the <button class='glossary-text'>Henderson-Hasselbalch equation</button> to calculate these volumes. An Example Calculation is given below for the 3.7 pH buffer in Figure 1.

pageData.desc: Figure 1: Equation showing calculation of a 3.7 pH buffer; the buffer requires 9.1 mL of 0.1 M acetic acid and 0.9 mL of 0.1 M sodium acetate
pageData.altText: Figure 1: Equation showing calculation of a 3.7 pH buffer; the buffer requires 9.1 mL of 0.1 M acetic acid and 0.9 mL of 0.1 M sodium acetate

pageData.text: The individual pipets should only be used with a single solution. Label them to prevent confusion and cross-contamination.

Activity 1 consists of two parts. In the first part, you will create a solution of sodium acetate, and measure out volumes of water, acetic acid, sodium hydroxide and hydrochloric acid. You will also create three different pH solutions using the calculations performed in the Preparation section. These eight liquids will be mixed in different combinations using a 24-well plate. You will determine the pH of each mixture using a pH indicator solution.In the second part, you will create additional amounts of the 4.7 pH buffer solution to create a serial dilution of the buffer solution. The undiluted buffer and each dilution will be added to the clean 24-well plate. You will observe the buffering capacity of the buffer solution as you add varying amounts of sodium hydroxide to the wells, using the pH indicator to observe the pH of each mixture.

typeBefore.title:
A
  Buffer Solution Preparation (10 steps)

pageData.text:
Based on the Preparation calculations, prepare 50 mL of a 0.10 M solution of sodium acetate in the cup labeled sodium acetate. Mix with a pipet until completely dissolved.
  1. Weigh out the calculated amount of sodium acetate using a weigh boat and the electronic balance.
  2. Pour the sodium acetate into the cup and add approximately 45 mL of pure water.
  3. Mix the solution with a pipet until completely dissolved.
  4. Pour the contents of the cup back into the cylinder and add water until the volume reaches 50 mL and return the solution to the cup.
  5. Rinse the graduated cylinder with pure water to avoid any cross contamination.
Add approximately 100 mL of pure water to the cup labeled water.
Use the 50-mL graduated cylinder to transfer 50 mL of 0.1 M acetic acid to the cup labeled acetic acid.
Add 10 drops of Bogen’s Universal Indicator to the acetic acid and the sodium acetate solutions. Add 20 drops of universal indicator to the 100 mL of water in the cup.

Prepare 10 mL of 0.1 M NaOH and 0.1 M HCl.
  1. Measure 1 mL of 1 M NaOH in the 10-mL graduated cylinder.
  2. Fill the graduated cylinder to 10 mL with pure water.
  3. Pour solution into the appropriately labeled cups.
  4. Rinse graduated cylinder thoroughly with pure water.
  5. Repeat dilution with 1 mL of 1 M HCl.
Add 2 drops of universal indicator to the NaOH and the HCl solutions.
Prepare the 3.7, 4.7, and 5.7 pH <button class='glossary-text'>buffer</button> solutions as calculated in the Preparation section. Pour the solutions into their respectively labeled cups.

The pipets are useful for transferring the stock solutions to the graduated cylinder for precise measurements. Each of the buffer solutions should be a different color. Refer to the indicator solution color chart to confirm the pH of your prepared buffers.
Place the 24-well plate on to a sheet of plain white paper. This will make it easier to compare the solution colors. Orient the plate vertically so that there are six rows and four columns of wells.
Add one drop of universal indicator to each well. This ensures that the colors will be bright when testing the solutions.

Use the graduation marks on the appropriate pipets to transfer the solutions (see Figure 2).
  1. 1 mL of 0.1 M acetic acid to all four wells in the first row of the 24-well plate.
  2. 1 mL of water to all four wells in the second row of the plate.
  3. 1 mL of 0.1 M sodium acetate solution to all four wells in the third row.
  4. 1 mL of the 3.7 pH buffer to all four wells in the fourth row.
  5. 1 mL of the 4.7 pH buffer to all four wells in the fifth row.
  6. 1 mL of the 5.7 pH buffers to all four wells in the sixth row.

pageData.desc: Figure 2: Diagram of 24-well plate showing locations of solutions for Activity 1 A
pageData.altText: Figure 2: Diagram of 24-well plate showing locations of solutions for Activity 1 A

pageData.text: Label the white paper with the solution names in each column and row for easy identification. Remember to only use the pipet for its specific solution to avoid cross-contamination.

typeBefore.title:
B
Observing Changes in pH (14 steps)

pageData.altText: camera symbol
pageData.text: Record the color of the solution for each row in Data table 1 and take a photo of the plate.
Match the row color to the indicator color chart and determine the approximate pH of the solution. Record this in Data table 1.
Do not add anything else to the first well of each row. These will be your color reference for the rest of the rows.
In the second well of each row, use the pipet to add one (1) drop of 0.1 M HCl.
Keeping the base of the plate on the table, gently swirl the solutions to mix them.
Record the resulting color and approximate pH of each solution in Data table 1.
In the third well of each row, add one (1) drop of 0.1 M NaOH.
Gently swirl the solution and record the color and approximate pH of each solution in your Data table 1.
Repeat the procedure in the fourth well of each row adding ten (10) drops of 0.1 M NaOH. Record the color and corresponding pH on Data table 1.

pageData.altText: camera symbol
pageData.text: Take a photo of the plate showing the colors in each well.
Empty the plate into the sink with running water. Rinse the plate with pure water, not tap water.
Dry the plate by placing it upside down on some paper towels. Tap it several times to remove most of the water.
Set aside the water, acetic acid, sodium acetate, and sodium hydroxide solutions. You will need them for the next part of the activity.
Empty the remaining plastic cups into the sink with running water.

typeBefore.title:
C
Buffering Capacity of a Solution (17 steps)

pageData.text: Turn the well plate 90° so that it is four rows by six columns.
In the cup labeled “4.7,” prepare 20 mL of 4.7 pH buffer by doubling the volumes calculated in the prelab.
Add 2 mL of this solution into all 6 wells in the first row. See Figure 3 below.

pageData.desc: Diagram of 24-well plate showing locations of solutions for Activity 1 B
pageData.altText: Diagram of 24-well plate showing locations of solutions for Activity 1 B

pageData.text: Dilute 5 mL of the 4.7 pH buffer solution with 15 mL of purified water containing the indicator and pour into a clean cup. This is the first dilution.
Add 2 mL of the first dilution to all the wells in the second row.
Dilute 5 mL of the first dilution with 15 mL of purified water containing indicator and pour into a clean cup. This is the second dilution.
Add 2 mL of the second dilution to all the wells in the third row.
Dilute 5 mL of the second dilution with 15 mL of purified water containing indicator and pour into a clean cup. This is the third dilution.
Add 2 mL of the third dilution to all the wells in the fourth row.

pageData.altText: camera symbol
pageData.text: Record the color of the first well of each row in Data table 2. You may need to add an additional drop of indicator to each well to make the color more visible and take a photo of the plate.
Add one (1) drop of 0.1 M NaOH solution to the second well in each row.
Do not add any NaOH solution to the first well of each row. This column will serve as a color reference for the remaining wells in the row.
Add two (2) drops of 0.1 M NaOH solution to the third well of each row.
Repeat with three (3) drops in the fourth well, four (4) drops in the fifth well, and five (5) drops in the sixth well.
Gently swirl the solutions until the color is uniform.
Record the color and corresponding pH of each well in the Data table 2.

pageData.altText: camera symbol
pageData.text: Take a photo of the plate showing the colors in each well.

Calculate the sodium acetate molar concentration of each dilution. Record the calculated values in Data table 2. The concentration of the 4.7 pH buffer is 0.05 M sodium acetate.Concentration(start) x Volume(start) = Concentration(final) x Volume(final)

pageData.title: Disposal and Cleanup
text: Dispose of solutions down the drain with the water running. Allow the faucet to run a few minutes to dilute the solutions.
Rinse and dry the lab equipment and return the materials to your equipment kit.

pageData.altText: completion

text: The pK<sub class=bodySubscript>a</sub> of acetic acid is 4.7. What is the buffering range of this acid and its conjugate base? Explain your answer.
Calculate the volume of 6 M acetic acid needed to prepare 100 mL of a 0.10 M acetic acid (CH<sub class=bodySubscript>3</sub>COOH) solution.
Calculate the mass of sodium acetate (CH<sub class=bodySubscript>3</sub>COONa) required to prepare 50 mL of a 0.10 M sodium acetate solution.
Calculate the volume of 1 M sodium hydroxide (NaOH) needed to prepare 10 mL of a 0.10 M sodium hydroxide solution.
Calculate the volume of 1 M hydrochloric acid (HCl) needed to prepare 10 mL of a 0.10 M hydrochloric acid solution.

Determine the volumes of 0.10 M CH<sub class=bodySubscript>3</sub>COOH and 0.10 M CH<sub class=bodySubscript>3</sub>COONa required to prepare 10 mL of the following pH buffers. (Note: the pK<sub class=bodySubscript>a</sub> of CH<sub class=bodySubscript>3</sub>COOH =4.7)
Write a balanced equation for the dissociation equilibrium of acetic acid.

In Activity 2, there were 2 mL of buffer per well. Calculate the final pH of the undiluted buffer after 0.25 mL of 0.1 M NaOH is added. The K<sub class=bodySubscript>a</sub> of CH<sub class=bodySubscript>3</sub>COOH = 1.8 × 10-5. Use the CH<sub class=bodySubscript>3</sub>COOH buffer concentration calculated in Data Table 2, a balanced CH<sub class=bodySubscript>3</sub>COOH + NaOH reaction equation, an ICE table, and a balanced dissociation equilibrium equation to help determine the pH.
What is the final pH of the second dilution after adding 1 drop of 0.1 M NaOH?

pageData.text: Make sure the well plate is placed on a clean surface; for enhanced contrast, a blank piece of paper can be placed under the plate.

  • Each row of the plate
  • Each well in each of the rows
  • The color differences in the wells

pageData.altText: Periodic Table of the Elements

pageData.content: Table 1. ICE table for the dissociation of acetic acid
pageData.title: Table 1.CH3COOH(aq) ⇄ H+(aq) + CH3COO-(aq)

pageData.altText: This map outlines the workflow for this investigation. Before starting any activities, you will label cups and pipets with solution names, calculate the mass of sodium acetate needed to make a sodium acetate solution, and determine the reactant volumes to prepare pH buffer solutions. In Activity 1, you will create or obtain eight different solutions, including three different pH buffer solutions. Then, you will mix these solutions together in different combinations within a 24-well plate. You will also observe the pH of each well via a pH indicator color change. Next, you will create a fresh batch of 4.7 pH buffer solution which you will add to the wells of a clean 24-well plate. You will then create three dilutions of the pH buffer solution and add these to the 24-well plate. You will add increasing volumes of sodium hydroxide to the plate wells and observe the pH of each well via a pH indicator color change. Finally, you will calculate the molar concentration of sodium acetate in each dilution.

pageData.content: Figure 1. Example calculation for determining pH buffer reactant volumes
pageData.altText: Figure 1: Equation showing calculation of a 3.7 pH buffer; the buffer requires 9.1 mL of 0.1 M acetic acid and 0.9 mL of 0.1 M sodium acetate

data.title: Acid dissociation constant ( K<sub class=bodySubscript>a</sub> )
data.content: The equilibrium constant of the dissociation reaction of an acid in aqueous solution, representing a dynamic balance between the acid in its intact and dissociated states

data.title: Buffer
data.content: Prevents the pH from becoming too low or too high

data.title: Henderson-Hasselbalch equation
data.content: Typically used to design a buffer of a targeted pH, pH = pK<sub class=bodySubscript>a</sub> + log ([Conjugate Base]/ [Weak Acid])

data.title: ICE table (Initial, Change, Equilibrium)
data.content: Can be helpful in determining the concentration of species when equilibrium shifts occur

data.title: pK<sub class=bodySubscript>a</sub>
data.content: Indicates the strength of an acid
